column1: 我是小李。
column2: Wǒ shì Xiǎo Lǐ.
column3: I am Xiao Li.

column1: 你是谁？
column2: Nǐ shì shéi?
column3: Who are you? (you are who?)

column1: A:这是什么？<br />B:这是我的iPad。
column2: Zhè shì shénme?<br />Zhè shì wǒ de iPad.
column3: What is this?<br />This is my iPad.

column1: A:你喜欢吃什么菜？<br />B:我喜欢吃中国菜。
column2: Nǐ xǐhuan chī shénme cài?<br />Wǒ xǐhuan chī Zhōngguó cài.
column3: What kind of food do you like?<br />I like Chinese food.

column1: A:你用什么手机？<br />B:我用iPhone。
column2: Nǐ yòng shénme shǒujī?<br />Wǒ yòng iPhone.
column3: What kind of cell phone do you use?<br />I use an iPhone.

column1: A:你在看什么书？<br />B:我在看小说。
column2: Nǐ zài kàn shénme shū?<br />Wǒ zài kàn xiǎoshuō.
column3: What kind of book are you reading?<br />I am reading a novel.

column1: A:他开什么车？<br />B:他开宝马。
column2: Tā kāi shénme chē?<br />Tā kāi Bǎomǎ.
column3: What kind of car does he drive?<br />He drives a BMW.

column1: A:你在哪里？<br />B:我在家。
column2: Nǐ zài nǎlǐ?<br />Wǒ zài jiā.
column3: Where are you?<br />I'm at home.
column7: Subj. + Verb + 哪里 / 哪儿 ?

column1: A:你要去哪儿？<br />B:我要去洗手间。
column2: Nǐ yào qù nǎr?<br />Wǒ yào qù xǐshǒujiān.
column3: Where are you going now?<br />I'm going to the bathroom.
column7: Subj. + Verb + 哪里 / 哪儿 ?

column1: A:我们在哪儿？<br />B:我们在南京西路。
column2: Wǒmen zài nǎr?<br />Wǒmen zài Nánjīng Xī Lù.
column3: Where are we?<br />We are at West Nanjing road.
column7: Subj. + Verb + 哪里 / 哪儿 ?

column1: A:这个周末你想去哪儿？<br />B:我想去公园。
column2: Zhège zhōumò nǐ xiǎng qù nǎr?<br />Wǒ xiǎng qù gōngyuán.
column3: Where do you want to go this weekend?<br />I want to go to the park.
column7: Subj. + Verb + 哪里 / 哪儿 ?

column1: A:你好，你要去哪儿？<br />B:我要去外滩。
column2: Nǐhǎo, nǐ yào qù nǎr?<br />Wǒ yào qù Wàitān.
column3: Hello, where do you want to go?<br />I want to go to the Bund.
column7: Subj. + Verb + 哪里 / 哪儿 ?

column1: A:你要哪个？<br />B:我要这个。
column2: Nǐ yào nǎge?<br />Wǒ yào zhège.
column3: Which one do you want?<br />I want this one.

column1: A:你喜欢哪个菜？<br />B:我喜欢这个菜。
column2: Nǐ xǐhuan nǎge cài?<br />Wǒ xǐhuan zhège cài.
column3: Which dish do you like?<br />I like this dish.

column1: A:我们去哪个饭店？<br />B:我们去你妈妈的饭店。
column2: Wǒmen qù nǎge fàndiàn?<br />Wǒmen qù nǐ māma de fàndiàn.
column3: Which restaurant are we going to?<br />We are going to your mom's restaurant.

column1: A:你在哪个房间？<br />B:我在你的房间。
column2: Nǐ zài nǎge fángjiān?<br />Wǒ zài  nǐ de fángjiān.
column3: Which room are you in?<br />I'm in your room.

column1: A:你住在哪个区？<br />B:我住在静安区。
column2: Nǐ zhù zài nǎge qū?<br />Wǒ zhù zài  Jìng'ān Qū .
column3: Which district do you live in?<br />I live in Jing'an District.

column1: A:你是谁？<br />B:我是他女朋友。
column2: Nǐ shì shéi?<br />Wǒ shì tā nǚpéngyou.
column3: Who are you?<br />I'm his girlfriend.

column1: A:她是谁？<br />B:她是我的老师。
column2: Tā shì shéi?<br />Tā shì wǒ de lǎoshī.
column3: Who is she?<br />She‘s my teacher.

column1: A:你不喜欢谁？<br />B:我不喜欢我的老板。
column2: Nǐ bù xǐhuan  shéi?<br />Wǒ bù xǐhuan wǒ de lǎobǎn.
column3: Who do you not like?<br />I don't like my boss.

column1: A:谁想去？<br />B:我想去。
column2: Shéi xiǎng qù?<br />Wǒ xiǎng qù.
column3: Who wants to go?<br />I want to go.

column1: A:谁想喝咖啡？<br />B:我想喝咖啡。
column2: Shéi xiǎng hē kāfēi?<br />Wǒ xiǎng hē kāfēi.
column3: Who wants to drink coffee?<br />I want to drink coffee.

column1: A:你什么时候来？<br />B:我明天来。
column2: Nǐ shénme shíhou lái?<br />Wǒ míngtiān lái.
column3: When are you coming?<br />I'm coming tomorrow.

column1: A:你们什么时候走？<br />B:我们下个月走。
column2: Nǐmen shénme shíhou zǒu?<br />Wǒmen xià gè yuè  zǒu.
column3: When are you guys leaving?<br />We're leaving next month.

column1: A:我们什么时候吃饭？<br />B:我们6点吃饭。
column2: Wǒmen shénme shíhou chīfàn?<br />Wǒmen liù diǎn chīfàn.
column3: When are we eating?<br />We're eating at 6:00.

column1: A:爸爸什么时候回来？<br />B:爸爸周末回来。
column2: Bàba shénme shíhou huílái?<br />Bàba zhōumò huílái.
column3: When is dad coming back?<br />Dad is coming back this weekend.

column1: A:你的飞机什么时候到上海？<br />B:晚上八点。
column2: Nǐ de fēijī shénme shíhou dào Shànghǎi?<br />Wǎnshang bā diǎn.
column3: When is your airplane arriving in Shanghai?<br />Eight o'clock this evening.

column1: A:你为什么学中文？<br />B:因为我在中国工作。
column2: Nǐ wèishénme xué Zhōngwén?<br />Yīnwèi wǒ zài Zhōngguó gōngzuò.
column3: Why do you study Chinese?<br />Because I'm working in China.

column1: A:他们为什么不喝咖啡？<br />B:因为咖啡很苦。
column2: Tāmen wèishénme bù hē kāfēi?<br />Yīnwèi kāfēi hěn kǔ.
column3: Why don't you drink coffee?<br />Because coffee is bitter.

column1: A:他为什么不来？<br />B:因为他很忙。
column2: Tā wèishénme bù lái?<br />Yīnwèi tā hěn máng.
column3: Why isn't he coming?<br />Because he is busy.

column1: A:你早上为什么不在？<br />B:因为我出去见朋友了。
column2: Nǐ zǎoshang wèishénme bù zài?<br />Yīnwèi wǒ chūqù jiàn péngyou le.
column3: Why were you not here this morning?<br />Because I went out to meet some friends.

column1: A:这些外国人为什么不喜欢中国？<br />B:因为中国人太多。
column2: Zhèxiē wàiguó rén wèishénme bù xǐhuan Zhōngguó?<br />Yīnwèi Zhōngguó rén tài duō.
column3: Why do these foreigners not like China?<br />Because China has a lot of people.

column1: A:你怎么学习中文？<br />B:我用GrammarWiki学习中文。
column2: Nǐ zěnme xuéxí Zhōngwén?<br />Wǒ yòng Grammar Wiki xuéxí Zhōngwén.
column3: How do you study Chinese?<br />I use the Grammar Wiki to study Chinese.

column1: A:你怎么上网？<br />B:我用手机上网。
column2: Nǐ zěnme shàngwǎng?<br />Wǒ yòng shǒujī shàngwǎng.
column3: How do you go online?<br />I use my cell phone to go online.

column1: A:你怎么去北京？<br />B:我坐火车去。
column2: Nǐ zěnme qù Běijīng?<br />Wǒ zuò huǒchē qù.
column3: How do you go to Beijing?<br />I take the train.

column1: A:你们怎么回家？<br />B:我开车回家。

column3: How are you guys going to get home?<br />I‘m driving home.

column1: A:你怎么买票？<br />B:我上网买票。
column2: Nǐ zěnme mǎi piào?<br />Wǒ shàngwǎng mǎi piào.
column3: How do you buy tickets?<br />I go online to buy tickets.

column1: A:太贵了！<br />B:好吧，我们可以看看别的。

column3: That's too expensive!<br />All right, we can take a look at something else.

column1: A:下午我不在家，你可以晚上来吗？<br />B:行吧。
column2: Xiàwǔ wǒ bù zài jiā, nǐ kěyǐ wǎnshang lái ma?<br />Xíng ba.
column3: This afternoon I won't be home. Can you come by this evening?<br />All right.

column1: A:雨太大了，明天再去买吧。<br />B:好吧，但是明天一定要买到。
column2: Yǔ tài dà le, míngtiān zài qù mǎi ba.<br />Hǎo  ba, dànshì míngtiān yídìng yào mǎidào.
column3: It's raining heavily. Let's go buy it tomorrow.<br />Fine, but tomorrow we definitely have to buy it.

column1: A:可以带朋友吗？<br />B:行吧，但是不能带女孩。
column2: Kěyǐ dài péngyou ma ?<br />Xíng  ba, dànshì bù néng dài nǚhái.
column3: Can I bring friends?<br />All right, but you can't bring girls.

column1: A:我今天不太舒服，你可以自己去吗？<br />B:好吧，那你好好休息。
column2: Wǒ jīntiān bù tài shūfu, nǐ kěyǐ zìjǐ qù ma?<br />Hǎo ba, nà nǐ hǎohǎo xiūxi.
column3: I'm not feeling well today. Can you go by yourself?<br />All right, rest well then.

column1: A:老板呢？<br />B:他走了。
column2: Lǎobǎn ne?<br />Tā zǒu le.
column3: Where is the boss?<br />He (already) left.

column1: A:孩子还在上大学吗？<br />B:他们工作了。
column2: Háizi hái zài shàng dàxué ma?<br />Tāmen gōngzuò le.
column3: Are your kids still in college?<br />They (already) work.
column4: This expression emphasizes that they're not students anymore, and have already entered the workforce.

column1: A:用我的车吧？<br />B:谢谢，我们有车了。
column2: Yòng wǒ de chē ba?<br />Xièxie, wǒmen yǒu chē le.
column3: How about using my car?<br />Thanks. We (already) have a car.

column1: A:你要不要告诉他？<br />B:他知道了。
column2: Nǐ yào bu yào gàosu tā?<br />Tā zhīdào le.
column3: Are you going to tell him?<br />He (already) knows.

column1: A:你应该问老师。<br />B:我问了。
column2: Nǐ  yīnggāi wèn lǎoshī.<br />Wǒ wèn le.
column3: You should ask the teacher.<br />I (already) asked.

column1: 她穿着一条小黑裙。

column3: She's wearing a little black dress.
column4: Be wearing is a state, so using 着 is natural.)

column4: Be wearing is not an action, so don't use 在.)

column3: It makes me most comfortable just lying there.
column4: Lying here is a state, so using 着 is natural.)

column1: 在躺最舒服。
column2: Zài tǎng zuì shūfu.
column4: Lying here is not strictly an action, so don't use 在.)

column1: 你不要生气，我是说着玩的。
column2: Nǐ bùyào shēngqì, wǒ shì shuō zhe wán de!
column3: Don't be mad. I was just joking.
column7: Subj. + 是 + Verb + 着 + 玩 + 的

column1: 我听不懂英文歌，只是听着玩的。
column2: Wǒ tīng bu dǒng Yīngwén gē, zhǐshì tīng zhe wán de.
column3: I don't understand English songs. I listen just for fun.
column7: Subj. + 是 + Verb + 着 + 玩 + 的

column3: You sit here. Don't go anywhere else.

column1: 家里的灯开着。

column4: Being on is a state, so using 着 is natural.

column2: Jiālǐ de dēng zài kāi.
column4: Being on is not an action, so don't use 在.

column2: Tā dài zhe yǎnjìng.
column4: Having his glasses (on him) is a state, so using 着 is natural.)

column1: 他在戴眼镜。
column2: Tā zài dài yǎnjìng.
column4: Having his glasses (on him) is not an action, so don't use 在.)

column1: 我不是认真的，我是闹着玩的。

column1: 你不要生气，我是说着玩的！
column2: Nǐ bùyào shēngqì, wǒ gāngcái shì shuō zhe wán de!
column3: Don't be mad.I was just joking.

column1: 你妹妹很漂亮嘛。
column2: Nǐ mèimei hěn piàoliang ma.
column3: Your sister is pretty.

column1: 他家挺有钱的嘛。
column2: Tā jiā tǐng yǒuqián de ma.
column3: His family is pretty rich.

column1: 不想去就不要去嘛。
column2: Bù xiǎng qù jiù bùyào qù ma.
column3: If you don't wanna go, don't go.

column1: 你别太谦虚嘛。
column2: Nǐ bié tài qiānxū ma.
column3: Don't be too modest.

column1: 大家有话就说嘛。
column2: Dàjiā yǒu huà jiù shuō ma.
column3: Guys, you should say whatever you want to say.

column1: 你跟他很熟嘛。
column2: Nǐ gēn tā hěn shóu ma.
column3: You two know each other well.

column1: 开慢点，安全第一嘛。
column2: Kāi màn diǎn, ānquán dìyī ma.
column3: Drive slowly. Safety first.

column1: 不用塑料袋更环保嘛。
column2: Bùyòng sùliàodài gèng huánbǎo ma.
column3: It's more environmental not to use plastic bags.

column1: 这个老外很了解中国文化嘛。
column2: Zhège lǎowài hěn liǎojiě Zhōngguó wénhuà ma.
column3: This foreigner know a lot about Chinese culture.

column1: 别担心，一边工作一边学嘛。
column2: Bié dānxīn, yībiān gōngzuò yībiān xué ma.
column3: Don't worry. You can learn while you work.

column1: 冬天去吧，太冷；夏天去吧，太热。
column2: Dōngtiān qù ba, tài lěng; xiàtiān qù ba, tài rè.
column3: Going in the winter, it's too cold; Going in the summer, it's too hot.

column1: 早点去吧，要等；晚点去吧，会堵车。
column2: Zǎo diǎn qù ba, yào děng; wǎn diǎn qù ba, yòu dǔchē.
column3: Going early, we'll have to wait; Going later, there will be too much traffic.

column1: 穿得多一点吧，会热；穿得少一点吧，会冷。
column2: Chuān de duō yīdiǎn ba, huì rè; chuān de shǎo yīdiǎn ba, huì lěng.
column3: Wearing a little more, it will be hot; Wearing a little less, it will be cold.

column1: 去吧，要给红包；不去吧，他没面子。
column2: Qù ba, yào gěi hóngbāo; bù qù ba, tā méi miànzi.
column3: Going there, I need to give a red envelope; Not going, he will lose face.

column1: 不说吧，他还会做错；说吧，他肯定不高兴。
column2: Bù shuō ba, tā hái huì zuò cuò; shuō ba, tā kěndìng bù gāoxìng.
column3: Not telling him, he will still do it wrong next time; Telling him, he must be upset.

column1: 回去吧，机票太贵；不回去吧，家人肯定会想我。
column2: Huíqù ba, jīpiào tài guì; bù huíqù ba, jiārén kěndìng huì xiǎng wǒ.
column3: Going back, the air ticket is too expensive; Not going back, my family definitely miss me.

column1: 带你去吧，你总是不听话；不带你去吧，你一个人肯定无聊。
column2: Dài nǐ qù ba, nǐ zǒngshì bù tīnghuà; bù dài nǐ qù ba, nǐ yīgèrén kěndìng wúliáo.
column3: Taking you with me, you will be naughty like always; Not taking you with me, you will definitely be bored.

column1: 见面吧，常常吵架；不见面吧，还是会想他。

column3: Seeing each other, we fight a lot; Not seeing each other, I miss him anyway.

column1: 不说真话吧，老婆不高兴；说真话吧，老婆也不高兴。

column3: Not speaking the truth, the wife will be upset; Telling the truth, the wife will also be upset.

column1: 这个老房子，卖吧，怕父母不同意；不卖吧，就没钱买新车。

column1: 你的妹妹很漂亮嘛。

column1: 他会好的。

column1: 你可以的。

column1: 她一定会来的。

column2: Wǒmen néng gǎodìng de.

column1: 我不会骗你的。

column1: 工作吧，太累；不工作吧，无聊。

column1: 买吧，不想花那么多钱；不买吧，又不开心。

column3: If I buy it, too expensive, but if I don't buy them, I won't be unhappy.

column1: 早去吧，需要等；晚去吧，会堵车。

column3: If we go early we'll have to wait, but if we go later, there will be too much traffic.

column1: 关于调查结果，我们也不太清楚。

column1: 这是一份关于中国奢侈品市场的报告。

column3: I saw a documentary about animal protection yesterday.

column1: 我们聊聊你的新工作吧。

column1: 今天开会要说说公司下个月的培训。

column3: Today, we need to hold a meeting about next month's company training.

column1: 直到十二点半，我才做完作业。

column1: 直到半个月以后，我的感冒才好。
column2: Zhídào bàn gè yuè yǐhòu, wǒ de gǎnmào cái hǎo.
column3: It took me half a month to recover from the cold.

column1: 她直到十八岁才见到亲生父母。
column2: Tā zhídào shíbā suì cái jiàndào qīnshēng fùmǔ.
column3: It wasn't until she was eighteen that she met her biological parents.

column1: 我直到大学毕业才开始独立生活。
column2: Wǒ zhídào dàxué bìyè cái kāishǐ dúlì shēnghuó.
column3: It wasn't until I graduated from college that I started living independently.

column1: 直到去了北京，他才知道一个人在大城市多辛苦。

column3: It wasn't until he went to Beijing that he understood how hard it is to be alone in a big city.

column1: 他们是同学，但是直到毕业，都没说过话。

column3: They are classmates. But they had never spoken until they graduated.
column7: 直到 + Time / Event ，Subj. + 都  + 不 / 没 ⋯⋯

column1: 直到电影结束，他都没来。
column2: Zhídào diànyǐng jiéshù, tā dōu méi lái.
column3: He never showed up until the movie was over.
column7: 直到 + Time / Event ，Subj. + 都  + 不 / 没 ⋯⋯

column1: 直到我弟弟上大学，他都不会洗衣服。
column2: Zhídào wǒ dìdi shàng dàxué, tā dōu bù huì xǐ yīfu.
column3: My younger brother could't wash clothes until he went to college.
column7: 直到 + Time / Event ，Subj. + 都  + 不 / 没 ⋯⋯

column1: 我姐姐比我大两岁。

column3: My sister is two years older than me.

column3: How much younger are you than your elder brother?

column3: His girlfriend is 10 years older than him.
column7: A + 比 + B + 大 / 小 + number + 岁

column7: A + 比 + B + 大 / 小 + number + 岁

column3: Who is elder between you two?

column3: Who is the elder one, your dad or your mom?

column3: Who is the youngest among the five of you?
column7: A + 比 + B + 大 / 小 + number + 岁

column3: My dad is about the same age with my mom.
column7: A + 跟 + B + 一样 / 差不多 + 大

column7: A + 跟 + B + 一样 / 差不多 + 大

column1: 给客人倒茶。

column1: 妈妈在给孩子们做饭。

column1: 我儿子喜欢给小狗洗澡。

column3: My son likes to give a bath to our dog.

column1: 请给我拿一双筷子。

column1: 可以给我买一杯咖啡吗？
column2: Kěyǐ gěi wǒ mǎi yī bēi kāfēi ma?
column3: Could you please buy me a cup of coffee?

column1: 可以给我拿一下行李吗？

column1: 这个周末我们给儿子开生日派对。

column3: We're going to hold a birthday party for our son this weekend.

column1: 我没带钥匙，你能给我开一下门吗？

column1: 这样做一方面能节省时间，一方面能提高质量。

column3: One one hand, this project can increase local people's income; on the other hand, it can protect local environment.

column1: 政府一方面要发展这些古城，一方面也要保护好这些古城。

column3: On one hand, the government need to develop these old towns; on the other hand, they need to protect them well.

column1: A:这件衣服有点儿贵啊。<br />B:是贵了一点儿，但是很好看，我很喜欢。
column3: This piece of clothing is a bit expensive.<br />It's a bit expensive, but it looks really good, I like it.

column1: A:服务员，这件衣服能不能便宜一点？<br />C:不好意思，不能还价，所以一点也不能便宜。
column3: Attendant, could we get this a little cheaper?<br />I'm sorry, no haggling. It can't be a little bit cheaper. Not even a bit.

column1: A:你也是大学生？你是什么专业的？<br />B:我是中文专业的。

column1: 他家的家具都是中式的。

column1: A:你是什么时候开始学中文的？<br />B:我是两年前开始学中文的。
column2: Nǐ shì shénme shíhou kāishǐ xué Zhōngwén de?<br />Wǒ shì liǎng nián qián kāishǐ xué Zhōngwén de.
column3: A: When was it that you started studying Chinese?<br />It was two years ago when I started studying Chinese.
column7: Subj. + 是 + [Information to be Emphasized] + Verb + 的

column1: A:你是在哪里学的中文？<br />B:我是在上海学的中文。

column3: Where is it that you study Chinese?<br />It's in Shanghai that I study Chinese.

column1: A:你们是什么时候到的？<br />B:我们是昨天到的。

column1: 我刚看到。

column1: 我刚看到了。
column2: Wǒ gāng kàndào le.
column3: I just saw it.
column4: 了 is not needed here as 看到 includes the result of "looking at."

column1: 我刚才看到了。
column2: Wǒ gāngcái kàndào le.
column3: I saw it just now.
column4: 了 is needed here as 刚才 always refers to the past.

column1: 你刚知道吗？
column2: Nǐ gāng zhīdào ma?

column4: The verb 知道 always includes the result of "knowing."

column1: 我刚听说。
column2: Wǒ gāng tīngshuō.

column4: The verb 听说 includes a clear enough indication of result.

column1: 宝宝刚醒。
column2: Bǎobao gāng xǐng.

column4: The verb 醒 includes a clear enough indication of result.

column1: 我刚没看到。
column2: Wǒ gāng méi kàndào.
column3: I just didn't see it.
column4: Don't use 刚 with 没 in the past.

column2: Wàiguó rén néng bu néng cānjiā?<br />Bù kěyǐ.
column3: Is it possible for foreigners to attend?<br />Impossible.

column1: 她才五岁，但是很会说话。
column2: Tā cái wǔ suì, dànshì hěn huì shuōhuà.
column3: She's only five but she's a smooth talker.
column4: The subject has good speaking skills.

column1: 他刚来。
column2: Tā gāng lái.
column3: He just came.
column4: This gives the impression that not only did he just get here, but he should still be here.

column1: 我昨天刚看到他。
column2: Wǒ zuótiān gāng kàndào tā.
column3: I just saw him yesterday.

column1: 我刚说过，不想再说一遍。
column2: Wǒ zuótiān gāng kàn dào tā.
column3: I just said it, and I don't want to say it again.

column1: 我们去年刚去过美国。
column2: Wǒmen qùnián gāng qù guo Měiguó.
column3: We've just been to the United States last year.
column4: This "just" is relative, clearly. The speaker feels that a year ago isn't too long ago.

column1: 他刚才来过。
column2: Tā  gāngcái lái guo.
column3: He came just now.
column4: In this case, he's come and gone already. He's not here anymore.

column1: 我刚才看过了，不想再看了。
column2: Wǒ gāngcái kàn guo le, bù xiǎng zài kàn le.
column3: I saw it just now, and I don't want to see it again.

column1: 我现在感觉比刚才好一点。
column2: Wǒ xiànzài gǎnjué bǐ gāngcái hǎo yīdiǎn.
column3: I feel a little better now than just before.

column1: 这些刚好。
column2: Zhèxiē gāng hǎo.
column3: These are just right.

column1: 我昨天买了。
column3: I bought it yesterday.

column1: 我刚才买了。
column3: I bought it just now.

column1: 我明天买。
column3: I'll buy it tomorrow.

column1: 我刚买。
column3: I just buy it.
column4: The verb 买 is kind of like "try to buy"; there is no clear indication of result.

column1: 我刚买到。
column3: I just bought it.
column4: Adding 到 to the verb gives a clear indication of result.

column1: 我刚买了。
column3: I just bought it.
column4: Adding 了 after the verb also gives a clear indication of result.

column1: 你也刚知道吗？
column3: You also just found out?
column4: The verb 知道 always includes the result of "knowing."

column1: 妈妈刚看。
column3: Mom just look.
column4: No clear indication of result.

column1: 妈妈刚看到。
column3: Mom just saw it.
column4: Adding 到 to the verb gives a clear indication of result.

column1: 妈妈刚看了。
column3: Mom just looked at it.
column4: Adding 了 to the verb gives a clear indication of result.

column1: 我刚没去。
column3: I just didn't go.
column4: Don't use 刚 with 没 in the past.

column1: 我刚才没去。
column3: I didn't go just now.
column4: It's fine to use 刚才 with 没 in the past.

column1: 她刚没问我这个问题。
column3: She just didn't ask me this question.
column4: Don't use 刚 with 没 in the past.

column1: 她刚才没问我这个问题。
column3: She didn't ask me this question just now.
column4: It's fine to use 刚才 with 没 in the past.

column1: 我刚没喝你的啤酒。
column3: I just didn't drink your beer.
column4: Don't use 刚 with 没 in the past.

column1: 我刚才没喝你的啤酒。
column3: I didn't drink your beer just now.
column4: It's fine to use 刚才 with 没 in the past.

column1: 我刚不知道。
column3: I just didn't know.
column4: OK, so it's not 没, but you still shouldn't use 刚 for something that didn't happen.

column1: 我刚才不知道。
column3: Just now I didn't know.
column4: It's fine to use 刚才 with exceptions where you use 不 in the past.

column1: 我刚才回家。
column3: I just now go home.
column4: You should use 了 with 刚才 here.

column1: 我刚回家。
column3: I just got home.
column4: The verb 回 includes a clear enough indication of result.

column1: 我刚没想好吃什么，现在我想好了。
column3: I just didn't make up my mind what to eat, now I've made up my mind.
column4: 刚 doesn't work with 没.

column1: 我刚才没想好吃什么，现在我想好了。
column3: Just now, I hadn't made up my mind what to eat, now I've made up my mind.
column4: No need to use 了 with 没.

column1: 他刚才没听懂我的话。
column3: He didn't understand what I said just now.
column4: No need to use 了 with 没.

column1: 他刚没听懂我的话。
column3: He just didn't understand what I said.
column4: 刚 doesn't work with 没.

column1: 我也是刚听说这个消息。
column3: I also just heard this news.
column4: The verb 听说 includes a clear enough indication of result.

column1: 我刚才听说了这个消息。
column3: I heard this news just now.
column4: You should use 了 with 刚才 here.

column1: 昨天他刚才来过。
column3: He just now came yesterday.
column4: 刚才 should be used for events a lot closer in time than 昨天.

column1: 昨天他刚来过。
column3: He just came yesterday.
column4: 刚 works with 昨天.

column1: A:你刚才去哪儿了？<br />B:我刚上完厕所。
column3: Where did you go just now?<br />I just got done in the bathroom.

column1: A:那你不知道刚才的事情吧？<br />B:是不是有人吵架了？
column3: Then you don't know what happened just now?<br />Did some people have an argument?

column1: 你喜欢他还是我？
column2: Nǐ xǐhuan tā háishì wǒ?
column3: Does you like him or me?
column7: Option A + 还是 + Option B ?

column1: 你可以坐1号线或者2号线去人民广场。

column3: You can take Line 1 or Line 2 to People's Square.

column3: We can contact each other by phone or email.

column1: 我想知道他们是支持还是反对。
column2: Wǒ xiǎng zhīdào tāmen shì zhīchí háishì fǎnduì.
column3: I'm wondering if they are with me or against me.

column1: 老板不确定是这个周末出差还是下个周末出差。

column3: The boss isn't sure if he's going on business trips this weekend or next weekend.

column1: 明天还是后天都行。

column3: Either tomorrow or the day after is fine.
column4: Since it is a statement, it should use 或者

column3: I'm wondering if that person is male or female.
column4: It's an embedded question, so it should use 还是

column1: 1977年他考上了大学，后来就没回过老家。
column3: In 1977, he went to college. He didn't come back to his hometown after that.

column1: 我们先去吃饭，然后去超市。

column3: I'm going to eat, then I'll go to the supermarket.

column1: 他先说了一个好消息，然后又说了一个坏消息。

column3: First he told the good news, then he told the bad news.

column1: 我们想先去美国，后来去加拿大。
我们想先去美国，然后去加拿大。
A:我先去你家，然后你和我一起去见她？<br />B:对。你们几年没见了？<br />A:两年前她出国了，后来就一直没见过她。
column3: First I'll go to your house, then you and I can go together to see her.<br />Sure. How many years has it been that you haven't seen each other?<br />She left the country two years ago. Since then, I haven't seen her.

column3: She left the country two years ago. Since then, I haven't seen her.

column1: 我不在乎人家怎么说。

column3: I need you to do as I say and also do it well.

column3: I informed everyone and also prepared all of the materials.

column3: Controlling your diet and also exercising more will give you a better and better figure.

column3: I agree with and support your decision.

column3: Even if it's raining tomorrow, we're still going to go out hiking.

column7: ⋯⋯ ，Subj. 不但 + 不 / 没 ⋯⋯，反而 + [Unexpected Outcome]

column3: Having failed so many times, he didn't give up. On the contrary, he worked even harder.

column3: Your mother loves you so much. You are not thankful to her at all. On the contrary, you said she doesn't care about you?

column3: I took the weight-loss pill. She didn't lose weight at all. On the contrary, I gained weight!

column3: Even if you only gave ten dollars in a red envelope, everyone would still be happy.

column3: I wouldn't marry him even if his father is the president!

column1: 哪怕你说得再好，我们也不相信。

column3: The manager is not going to give you a pay raise no matter how hard you work.

column3: No matter how many times you ask her, she will not say a single word.

column3: Even if I‘m super busy, I will still find some time to visit my parents back home.

column3: Even if it's really exhausting, she doesn't want her parents' help with the baby.

column1: 老板肯定了我们团队的工作。

column1: 我们还没有确定什么时候开始。

column1: 我们要先肯定一个形式才能开始做。
column4: In this sentence, "肯定" needs  to be followed by a noun or a noun phrase.

column1: 我们要先确定一个形式才能开始做。
column3: We'll have to decide on a design before we can start working.

column1: 老板肯定了最近我工作很努力。
column4: In this sentence, "肯定" needs to be followed by a noun or noun phrase.

column1: 老板肯定了最近我的努力工作。
column3: The boss approved my recent hard work.
column4: By changing the word order, we get a noun phrase instead of a verb phrase.

column1: 他肯定还没起床，因为他的手机现在还没开机。
column3: He definitely hasn't gotten out of bed yet， because his phone is still off.

column1: 这次我肯定不骗你，骗你是小狗，好吧？
column3: I'm not lying this time. Cross my heart.
column4: The idiom "骗你是小狗" literally means "To deceive you is to be a small dog." It doesn't have a good English equivalent.

column1: 明天你们一定要来。
column3: You guys are definitely going to come tomorrow.

column1: 这件事和他有一定的关系，不能都怪你。

column1: 与其自己乱想，不如当面问清楚。

column1: 与其帮别人打工，还不如自己当老板。
column3: I'd rather to work for myself than work for other people.

column1: 与其麻烦别人，不如自己想办法。
column3: Instead of troubling other people, I'd rather think of the solution.

column1: 与其随便找一个男朋友，我宁愿单身。
column3: I'd rather stay single than find a random one.
column7: 与其 ⋯⋯ ，Subj. + 宁可 / 宁愿 ⋯⋯

column1: 与其去上一个三流的大学，我宁可先工作。
column3: Instead of going, I‘d rather start to work first.
column7: 与其 ⋯⋯ ，Subj. + 宁可 / 宁愿 ⋯⋯

column1: 与其住在陌生的大城市，爷爷宁可住农村的老房子。
column3: My grandfather would rather live in the old house in the countryside than stay in strange big city.
column7: 与其 ⋯⋯ ，Subj. + 宁可 / 宁愿 ⋯⋯

column1: 与其一直互相伤害，我宁愿早点分手。
column3: I'd rather break up with sooner him than keep hurting each other.
column7: 与其 ⋯⋯ ，Subj. + 宁可 / 宁愿 ⋯⋯

column1: 一样多的钱，与其在市区买一个小房子，我们宁愿在郊区买大房子。
column3: We'd rather to buy a big house in suburban area than buy a small one in the city area with the same amount of money.
column7: 与其 ⋯⋯ ，Subj. + 宁可 / 宁愿 ⋯⋯

column1: 与其说他是我的老师，不如说他是我的朋友。
column3: I'd rather say that he's my friend than my teacher.
column7: 与其说 + A，不如说 + B

column1: 与其说她是在帮你，不如说她是在帮她自己。
column3: I'd rather say that she's helping you than she's helping herself.
column7: 与其说 + A，不如说 + B

column1: 与其说他是在做饭，还不如说他是在玩。
column3: I'd rather say that he was playing than cook.
column7: 与其说 + A，不如说 + B

column1: 与其说它是一部爱情电影，不如说它是一部动作电影。
column3: I'd rather say it's a action movie than a love movie.
column7: 与其说 + A，不如说 + B

column1: 与其说他是在鼓励我，不如说是在批评我。
column3: I'd rather say that he was criticizing me than encouraging me.
column7: 与其说 + A，不如说 + B

column1: 凡是用鸡蛋做的菜，他都不喜欢。
column3: As long as the food is made of egg, he wouldn't like.
column7: 凡是 +  Noun / Noun Phrase＋都 / 就 / 一律 / 无不＋ Verb

column1: 凡是不听话的孩子都没有糖吃。
column3: As long as the kid doesn't behave well, he won't get any candy to eat.
column7: 凡是 +  Noun / Noun Phrase＋都 / 就 / 一律 / 无不＋ Verb

column1: 在中国，凡是想上大学的学生，就要通过高考。
column3: In China, as long as the student wants to go to college, he needs to pass the college entrance exam.
column7: 凡是 +  Noun / Noun Phrase＋都 / 就 / 一律 / 无不＋ Verb

column1: 凡是会员都可以参加这个活动。
column3: As long as you have a membership, you can can attend this activity.
column7: 凡是 +  Noun / Noun Phrase＋都 / 就 / 一律 / 无不＋ Verb

column1: 凡是美国公民都可以投票，这是真的吗？
column3: As long as you're an American citizen, you can vote. Is this true?
column7: 凡是 +  Noun / Noun Phrase＋都 / 就 / 一律 / 无不＋ Verb

column1: 凡是在这个行业工作过的人都知道市场竞争很厉害。
column3: As long as people worked in this industry, they would know that the market competition is very bad.
column7: 凡是 +  Noun / Noun Phrase＋都 / 就 / 一律 / 无不＋ Verb

column1: 凡是使用过兴奋剂的运动员一律会受到严重的惩罚。
column3: As long as the athletes have taken stimulants, they will be punished very seriously.
column7: 凡是 +  Noun / Noun Phrase＋都 / 就 / 一律 / 无不＋ Verb

column1: 美国最好的大学莫过于哈佛大学。
column3: For America's best college, nothing is better than Harvard.
column7: Topics or questions + 莫过于 + answer

column1: 人生中最悲伤的事情莫过于失去你爱的人。
column3: Nothing is sadder in life than losing a loved one.
column7: Topics or questions + 莫过于 + answer

column1: 让她最难过的莫过于你对她大喊大叫。
column3: Nothing makes her sadder than you shouting at her.
column7: Topics or questions + 莫过于 + answer

column1: 我能想到最浪漫的事莫过于跟你一起白头到老。
column3: The most romantic thing I can imagine is getting old together with you.
column7: Topics or questions + 莫过于 + answer

column1: 对父母来说最大的安慰莫过于孩子能开始独立生活了。
column3: To parents, nothing is more comforting than their kids being able to lead independent lives.
column7: Topics or questions + 莫过于 + answer

column1: 我们要出发的时候，他竟然说不去了。
column3: When we were ready to set out, he suddenly said he wasn't going.

column1: 这是一件让人难过的事情，你竟然还笑？
column3: This is something that makes people sad, but you are actually laughing?

column1: 他那么努力，竟然没考及格！
column3: He is so hardworking, but, surprisingly, he didn't pass the exam.

column1: 那个人骗了你的钱，你竟不生他的气？
column3: You got ripped off by that guy.

column1: 我不让他喝那么多，他非要喝。
column3: I don't want him to drink so much, but he had to.

column1: 我不想说，可是她非要让我说不可。
column3: I didn't want to tell, but she made me tell.

column1: 天那么冷，可是孩子非要穿裙子不可。
column3: It's so cold outside, but the child had to wear skirt.

column1: 他自己可以解决这个问题，干嘛非要你去帮他？
column3: He can solve this problem by himself. Why would you have to help him?

column1: 情人节那天，我女朋友非要让我给她买玫瑰花。
column3: My girlfriend had to ask me to buy her roses on Valentine's Day.

column1: 我根本不知道如何有效地管理。
column3: I just don't know how to manage effectively.

column1: 你为什么说昨天在街上看到我了？我根本没有出去！
column3: Why did say you saw me on the street yesterday? I didn't even go out!

column1: 他只是一个小孩子，根本没见过这么吓人的事情。
column3: He's just a small kid. He hasn't ever seen such scary stuff.

column1: 今天新同事又迟到了，他到底想不想在这里做了？
column3: The new co-worker came late again today. Does he want to work here or not?

column1: 你的包这么重！你到底带了多少东西？
column3: Your bag is so heavy! How much stuff are you even carrying?

column1: 会议已经开了两个小时了，我们到底什么时候结束？
column3: The meeting has already been going on for two hours. When on earth are we going to finish?

column1: 我到底不知道为什么我女朋友很生气。
column4: 到底 is normally used for questions.

column1: 我根本不知道为什么我女朋友很生气。
column4: 根本 emphasizes the negation.

column1: 他到底没有听我的话。
column4: 到底 is normally used for questions.

column1: 他根本没有听我的话。
column4: 根本 emphasizes the negation.

column1: 老板还没有透露我们根本能发多少奖金.
column4: 根本 should be used with negations

column1: 老板还没有透露我们到底能发多少奖金.
column4: 到底 is used to emphasize the speaker's impatience.

column1: 那么，你们根本为什么不喝酒呢？
column4: 根本 should be used to emphasize the negation, not the question.

column1: 那么，你们到底为什么不喝酒呢？
column4: 到底 emphasizes the question.

column1: 据实报道
根据实报道
根据事实报道
据说他去上海了。
根据说他去上海了。
据传首相将要辞职。
根据传首相将要辞职。
